item.title: personal
item.description:
recommendations

Currently, I do not take in as much media as I did prior to grad. school. However, of the few I have paid attention to, these I would recommend to anyone who asks.

movies

  • harry potter 1 - 8. (worthy highlights - harry potter and the goblet of fire, harry potter and the deathly hallows II)

series

  • game of thrones
  • friends (worthy highlight - seasons 4-7, ross‚Äô divorces and chandler‚Äôs comedic shine)
  • new girl (nick and schmidt are well written and acted)
  • normal people
  • atypical (much thanks to the creators and writer of this.)
  • avatar: the last airbender.

music

  • ramin djawadi - light of the seven
  • drake - 8am in charlotte (instrumental)
  • wheezy -who you foolin (instrumental)

books

  • khaled hosseni - kite runner
  • khaled hosseni - a thousand splendid suns
  • neal schusterman - scythe trilogy

item.title: professional
item.description:
PhD, Computational Biophysics

In December 2021, I came to the US on an F1 to study Bioinformatics at Georgia State University. I met Dr Gozem, my now supervisor during my Masters and liked working with him. I also met the other members of his lab and enjoyed talking theoretical chemistry and life with them. I joined the Gozem lab and began learning from them, still am.

BSc, Biochemistry

When I was 15, I got admitted to Landmark University, Kwara State, Nigeria to study Biochemistry. I was new to the acedemy and curious. By the second year, the chemistry and biochemistry began to make sense and I saw I had a connection with it. I also met friends I have till today and some objectively good professors.

item.title: vdw-surfgen
item.description:
Wrote the titular package because we care about supramolecular chemistry.

I will come back someday to clarify the Fibonnacci sphere algorithm, but for now, the gist is that the code uses the generation of an evenly spaced point sphere around a group of points in space to generate the Van der-Waals surface for a molecule.

It counts the atoms as the origin points and the atomic VdW surfaces as the spheres. Then it excludes crossing points between spheres to create the accurate molecular VdW surface.

item.title: Claude Code Fix
item.description:
Tried installing clade code and it seemed to work the first time, but when I tried running with the claude command, I got this error:

npm error code EACCES
npm error syscall rename
npm error errno -13
npm error
npm error Your cache folder contains root-owned files, due to a bug in
npm error previous versions of npm which has since been addressed.
npm error

The fix was:

sudo chown -R $(whoami):$(id -gn) ~/.npm ~/.npm-global
npm install -g @anthropic-ai/claude-code

literally 2 lines.

item.title: Munger 2007
item.description:
I watched Charlie Munger‚Äôs 2007 Commencement Speech and took notes. Below is a personal summary.

Avoid:

  1. Ideology:
    Don‚Äôt argue for a position unless you can argue for the other side better than they can.

  2. The four horsemen: Self-pity, envy, resentment and revenge. Use misfortunewhen it comes. This is learnable behavior.

  3. Perverse incentives / associations: Don‚Äôt work for people / ideas you don‚Äôt admire.

Develop:

  1. Competence: The way to get what you want is to deserve it. The way to do that is to maintain intense interest and assiduity. Be the most competent trustworthy person and the world will open up. People appreciate a seamless web of deserved trust.

item.title: Psi4 Installation
item.description:
Started the MOLSSI Quantum Chemistry class. I‚Äôve heard Psi4 in passing but I‚Äôve not used it yet.

Chose to install it with conda - avoiding any dependency issues. Tried others on the psicode manual, which I had to eventually unistall and restart with the following:

conda create -n psi4env -c conda-forge python=3.8 psi4
conda activate psi4env

this passed or skipped all of psi4 --test , but only after conda install pytest.

PS: I am on a 2020 Mac-M1.

item.title: Scythe Trilogy
item.description:
I read the three books, the most I had read in a while. In fact, I finished the last 2 in less than 2 weeeks from the time I picked up book 2 in February.

On the main characters:

  1. Faraday - Wise and human.
  2. Citra - Brilliant and strongwilled.
  3. Rowan - Ruthless and romantic.
  4. Curie - Protective and Respectable.
  5. Goddard - Cunny, Capricious but worse in the fictional world, Damningly Unrelatable.
  6. Tolliver - Liked this character. He was written like a person.
  7. Thunderhead - Provided a way to imagine God’s magnanimity.

Lines that made me feel and think:

  1. ‚ÄúAnd Morrison was left to wrestle with himself. He hated doing that, because he was a formidable opponent.‚Äù This made me laugh, it was like looking in a mirror.
  2. ‚ÄúTo say he was an indecisive man was an understatement. He might have seemed confident to others, but the truth was he‚Äôd never made a decision that he hadn‚Äôt come to regret on some level‚Äîwhich is why he often let decisions be made for him.‚Äù
  3. ‚ÄúI long for the luxury of being impractical. It would add‚Ä¶ texture‚Ä¶ to my existence.‚Äù
  4. ‚Äú‚ÄúTime passes so slowly, so smoothly,‚Äù it said. ‚ÄúAnd the atmospheric conditions! A tailwind at 8.6 kilometers per hour easing the flow of twenty-nine knots, the air at 70% humidity, but the numbers are nothing compared to the feel of it upon the skin‚Äù‚Äù Here, The Thunderhead highlights the satisfaction and even rarer, the beauty of experiencing things over analyzing them, something I stand to benefit from.
  5. ‚ÄúThe rest of the world saw them both as symbols. Intangible light to guide them in the darkness. She understood now why ancient peoples turned their heroes into constellations.‚Äù This solidified my understanding of the word ‚Äúluminaries‚Äù or naming stars and planets after heroes or great people. You want something to highlight and remind you of their greatness. It gives hope when needed.
  6. ‚ÄúAs long as when bad things happened, they happened somewhere else, to someone they didn‚Äôt know, it was not their problem.‚Äù This got at the heart of a problematic philosophy of mine. I have begun to fix it - especially in my mind - as I can better reason through the funnel from the current victims to me, but the practicality and allure of this thinking is not lost on me.
  7. ‚ÄúAs long as remorse is sincere, and one is willing to make recompense, there is no purpose to suffering.‚Äù Perhaps this is part of why God forgives, because our suffering post remorse and repentance has no point.
  8. ‚ÄúThou shalt lead an exemplary life in word and deed, and keep a journal of each and every day.‚Äù To me it seems that the latter is what evokes the first. Poring over myself - successes and mistakes - helps me understand or even define what a good life could look like for me, talk less of an exemplary one.
  9. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not about age, it‚Äôs about stagnation.‚Äù A character said this when discussing choosing who to glean.
  10. ‚Äú‚ÄúHe‚Äôs always asking me how I am, and if there‚Äôs anything I need. And if there is, he always makes sure I get it. Just last week I asked for a‚Äî‚Äù ‚Äú‚ÄîNo, not that kind of talking,‚Äù said Rowan, cutting her off. ‚ÄúI mean real talking. Has he ever hinted as to why you matter so much to him?‚Äù‚Äù Here Rowan describes small and big talk. I enjoy the distinction.
  11. ‚ÄúWailing that the sky is falling does nothing to stop it.‚Äù Do something.
  12. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt change the tide by spitting in the sea.‚Äù Accept what you can‚Äôt change.
  13. ‚Äú‚ÄúPeople are vessels,‚Äù Jeri had said to her. ‚ÄúThey hold whatever‚Äôs poured into them‚Äù.‚Äù
  14. ‚ÄúTime is never of the essence until someone decides that it is.‚Äù
  15. ‚Äúan infant is unaware of its own consciousness until it understands enough about the world to know that consciousness comes and goes, until it comes no more.‚Äù Perhaps the author here means consciousness as in life and death, or as in attention to the self.
  16. ‚Äúbuilding a sandbox around a domineering child, then allowing that child to preside over it, frees the adults to do the real work.‚Äù
  17. ‚Äútheater is the hallmark of ritual, and ritual is the touchstone of religion‚Äù. I noticed it in the regalia of Catholicism and the performances of Pentecostalism. Some aspects of it are genuine, but it feels sometimes that the person on stage is performing.
  18. ‚ÄúIncrimination in a world without crime or nations.‚Äù This joke by Baba, made me rememeber that crime is primarily based on the nation.
  19. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not enough for you to know‚Äîyou‚Äôve got find it‚Äîso you can show others how to find it, too.‚Äù It‚Äôs one thing to know the answer, its a better thing to know how to figure out the answer. I enjoy experiencing the second.
  20. ‚ÄúNothing in history was a firsthand account, and things known really meant things that were allowed to be known‚Äù

Good Lines:

  1. “Goddard was brilliant at finding shapes in the clouds of his fury.” “More whim than wisdom. "
  2. ‚ÄúWe couldn‚Äôt count our chickens before they were hatched.‚Äù ‚ÄúOr put our eggs in one basket,‚Äù added Baba. ‚ÄúI wonder which expression came first, the chickens or the eggs.‚ÄùüòÇ
  3. ‚ÄúDress quickly‚Äîwe must leave in extreme haste,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll be hasty in the morning,‚Äù she told him. üòÇ
  4. ‚ÄúWe are scythes, we are harm‚Äôs way.‚Äù
  5. ‚Äú‚Ä¶preferred not to have an audience for their audiences.‚Äù
  6. ‚ÄúA voice that resounded even when it whispered.‚Äù Cool possibility.

item.title: Logistic Regression
item.description:
logistic regression

here the predicted outputs are binary, either a 0 or a 1, therefore the challenge is finding an equation that can translate the input features to either of the choices.

To do this, they use the sigmoid function,viz:

f(x)=11+e‚àíz f(x)= \frac{1}{1+e^{-z}}

where z is w‚Éó.x‚Éó+b\vec{w}.\vec{x} + b .

This means if z is high or simply +ve, e‚àíze^{-z} is very small and f(x) approaches 1 - thus, it is approximated as 1. And for the erverse, it is approximately 0. This way all the data is transformed.

item.title: Z Score Normalization
item.description:
z-score normalization:

This is a way to make all features in the dataset have the same unit (the œÉ\sigma ).

Z=X‚àíŒºœÉ Z = \frac{X - \mu}{\sigma}

steps are:

  1. get mean of feature from all examples ( Œº\mu )
  2. get deviation from mean for each item
  3. square values from (2) and sum them all
  4. Take average of (3), i.e. (3) / m where m is no. of examples
  5. Get (4)\sqrt{(4)} ( œÉ\sigma )

When you do this for each sample feature in a feature set, the range will hence be from +b œÉ\sigma (gotten from the z norm for number highest from mean) to -b œÉ\sigma (gotten from the z norm for number lowest from mean) with 0 in the middle (i.e. the mean), where b is a scalar. so cool to understand why they are called “scalar”, because they literally scale what they multiply.

item.title: Multifeature Linear Regression
item.description:
the math:

Logically same as univariate here, just instead of single ww and xx there are multiple. It isalso more efficient to express all weights and features as vectors w‚Éó\vec{w} and x‚Éó\vec{x} . This way their dot product ( w‚Éó\vec{w} ‚ãÖ\cdot x‚Éó\vec{x} )is efficiently handled.

thus the equation becomes:

fw‚Éó,b(x‚Éó(i))=w‚Éó‚ãÖx‚Éó(i)+b f_{\vec{w},b}(\vec{x}^{(i)}) = \vec w\cdot \vec{x}^{(i)} + b

And the cost function J(w,b)=12m‚àëi=0m‚àí1(fw,b(x(i))‚àíy(i))2J(w,b) = \frac{1}{2m} \sum\limits_{i = 0}^{m-1} (f_{w,b}(x^{(i)}) - y^{(i)})^2 would be changed to:

J(w‚Éó,b)=12m‚àëi=0m‚àí1(fw‚Éó,b(x‚Éó(i))‚àíy(i))2 J(\vec{w},b) = \frac{1}{2m} \sum\limits_{i = 0}^{m-1} (f_{\vec{w},b}(\vec{x}^{(i)}) - y^{(i)})^2

For gradient descent and the derivatives:

item.title: Numpy and Tensors
item.description:
this is a summary of my understanding of the optional lab on covered numpy, arrays, vectors and matrices.

because we will be working with huge sets of data and we‚Äôll be manipulating weights, properties and biases repeatedly, we need to do these operations efficiently. Thus, the numpy package can help as it has vectors and matrix properties, which are faster and less memory intensive compared to hardcoded calculations.

to create both matrices and vectors the np.array syntax is typically used as such:

item.title: Richard Hamming, On Work
item.description:
Today, I read the transcript of Hamming’s You and your research talk found here and that‚Äôll be the 2nd material of his I‚Äôll come in contact with. I think it‚Äôs a good idea to write down its essence for me.

How to choose work:

  1. Think before you work. Just hard work is not enough - it must be applied sensibly.
  2. Work on important problems. At least with these, the unavoidable struggle to make something could be worthwhile.
  3. Work on solutions you can see. ‚ÄúIt’s not the consequence that makes a problem important, it is that you have a reasonable attack‚Äù.
  4. Work on scalable solutions. Do not solve an isolated problem except as characteristic of a class.
  5. Work on things you‚Äôre bold about. ‚ÄúOnce you get your courage up and believe that you can do important problems, then you can‚Äù.

How to work:

  1. Don‚Äôt let up. ‚ÄúThe good man gets on with the job, given what he’s got, and gets the best answer he can‚Äù. Alter the problem if necessary.
  2. Given two people of approximately the same ability and one person who works ten percent more than the other, the latter will more than twice outproduce the former.
  3. Practice tolerating ambiguity. Don‚Äôt wait to know everything.
  4. When you choose one thing, let go of all else and keep your thoughts on it. Your subconscious will appreciate this clarity.
  5. You can educate your bosses.¬†If you want to do something, don’t ask, do it. Present them with an accomplished fact. Don’t give them a chance to tell you ‚ÄúNo‚Äú.
  6. Learn to work with the system, and you will go as far as the system will support you. Or you can fight it steadily, as a small undeclared war, for the whole of your life.
  7. The appearance of conforming gets you a long way.
  8. Learn to use yourself. Your ego is good when used for your benefit.
  9. For creative living, get your problems clear and refuse to look at any answers until you’ve thought of a solution. E.g read to be updated, not to copy answers.
  10. After acheiving competency in a field, pivot. It takes courage to say, ‚ÄúYes, I will give up my great reputation‚Äù.

Why people do not do great work:

  1. they don’t work on important problems,
  2. they don’t become emotionally involved,
  3. they don’t try and change what is difficult to what is easily done but is still important,
  4. they keep giving themselves alibis for this hesitation to change.

item.title: linear regression and gradient descent
item.description:
This is a short summary of the first week of the machine learning course by Andrew Ng.

First thing he covered was the difference between supervised and unsupervised learning, but I currently care about the former.

supervised ml: Giving the computer a data set with sample answers of interest and telling it ‚Äúfind the correlation between the dataset and the answers of interest‚Äù or more simply, “learn how to get me the answers I care about given this dataset”.

item.title: ml start
item.description:
i want to continue posting online regularly.

hence this first post.

i started learning ml with andrew ng’s ml specialization.

notes:

  1. last week, i took a hpc course from uc boulder and took some notes. i am going to make a post about it.
  2. i learned qchem prints S0 -> SX transition energies at SX optimized geometry, so this is technically not adiabatic excitation energy. at the back of my mind, i am going “why would they do that instead of SX energy at SX optimized geometry - S0 energy at S0 optimized geometry?”, which is indeed what i typically need when doing calculations. apparently, S2 energy at S2 energy - S0 energy at S2 minimum is called the vertical emission energy, while, the adiabatic excitation energy (AEE) is instead the S2 energy at the S2 minimum - S0 energy at the S0 geometry and i didn’t know the difference.
  3. i learned a trick to color the files and folders differently in the terminal - ls --color. added this as an ls alias in my .bashrc and i like the view.
